Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The University of Texas Austin proposes Project Engage! to address the shortage of high school computer science (CS) students and teachers. The main components of this initiative are
(1) a novel dual enrollment (DE) CS Principles course for which high school students receive college credit, (2) a revamped college course that aligns with this DE course, and (3) a summer institute that trains in-service teachers to teach this DE course. The DE CS Principles course is innovative in three ways: First, it uses blended instruction in which classes are led by a high school teacher who is supported by online resources; second, it uses a problem-based curriculum that makes students active participants in the learning process; and third, it builds online learning communities for both students and teachers.
The online learning environment is central to this project because it provides teachers with instant access to pedagogical and curricular support, it provides teachers with an online community, allowing them to communicate with other teachers and discuss common concerns and successes, and it enables students to collaborate across traditional geographic and institutional boundaries.

This project promises significant impact in three dimensions. First, it will expand the CS community's supply of both students and teachers. The DE course can reach the 65% of Texas high schools that currently offer no AP CS courses. The summer institutes will train current math, CS, and science teachers to teach the DE course, and these teachers will receive on-going support from the online learning environment in the areas of course content and pedagogy. Second, it will significantly broaden participation among girls and under-represented minorities. DE courses disproportionately benefit students of lower socio-economic levels; anecdotal evidence suggests that the CS Principles course will attract a broader segment of the population, including girls; and the student-centered approach will engage students across all demographics, making computing relevant to their lives, their personal interests, and their future. Third, it will set a new standard for online CS education, answering many scientific questions about the impact and effectiveness of using blended instruction, problem-based learning, and online communities in a DE course.

This project will implement pilot DE courses at 6 Texas high schools, with the goals of eventually scaling this effort to several hundreds of Texas high schools and replicating the effort in other states through
the UTeach Institute.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The University of Texas at Austin's (UT) Project Engage seeks to increase the number and diversity of students who study computer science (CS),as well as the number of high school CS teachers in the state of Texas.
To meet these goals, Project Engage has designed and implemented anovel CS Principles course (Thriving in Our Digital World) that has three defining characteristics.  First, it is a dual enrollment (DE) course in which students receive both high school and UT credit, which is significant because DE courses have been shown to disproportionately benefit those students who are most at-risk of not attending college, including under-represented minorities.  Second, it uses a student-focused, project-based learning pedagogy, which improves student engagement, improves student retention of knowledge, and develops essential skills for college and beyond.  Third, it builds online learning communities for both students and teachers.
This project also provides professional development for teachers through its Summer Institutes for Teachers (SIT) and its ongoing school-year support. The goal is not just to develop teachers' content knowledge but to also improve their pedagogical skills.

Impact on Students and Teachers
From 2012 to 2016, this project has trained approximately 45 teachers to offer Thriving in Our Digital World to approximately 1300 students in Texas. As the project has progressed, we have been successful in expanding the pipeline of CS students, specifically in under-represented populations.  When the course was first launched in 2012, student gender, ethnicity, and race demographics showed a more diverse student population than was present in AP Computer Science A.
    
                         Thriving in Our                  AP Computer Science A     
                         Digital World(%)          Texas(%)          United States(%)
Female            30.3       23.5             19.2
African-American        6.7         3.6                 3.9
Hispanic                 32.9              19.2               8.3

Today, our demographics show an even greater increase in the diversity of students who are engaging with CS:
     
            2016/2017 Thriving in Our         
                Digital World (%)
Hispanic:       61.8
American Indian:        9.5
African-American:             7.4
Two or More Races:           7.1


Training and Support for Teachers
The Summer Institute for Teachers is an intensive 9-day professional development program to acquaint teachers with the course.  New teachers attend the entire program, while returning teachers return for three days, both to share their experiences and to continue their training.  Last summer's SIT was the largest so far, with 16 new teachers.  Qualitative feedback indicates that the vast majority of these teachers viewed the professional development as some of the most rigorous and rewarding that they had ever attended. Additionally, teachers return for one-day workshops during both the Fall and Spring semesters.  Online video conferences are held monthly so that the cohort can address challenges, share new learning, and continue to network with other CS teachers across the state of Texas. 

Differentiation
Over half of the assignments in the Thriving in Our Digital World curriculum are differentiated assignments.  These assignments offer top-performing students in the class additional challenges, research, and investigations.  Additionally, there are four honors projects that are included to supplant the end-of-module projects for more advanced students. These honors projects require the students to focus on an area of interest within a contextual framework and to devise creative solutions around the project's central question.

Alternative Assessments
A badging system was developed this past Spring and and has been deployed inthe 2016/2017 offering of the course.  The badges are a unique way of assessing students on 5 major skills identified in the Texas College and Career Readiness standards as essential to post-secondary success: intellectual inquisitiveness, problem solving, academic tenacity, group collaboration, and time management.  These badges are accompanied by aseries of research-aligned rubrics so that teachers can assess students on avariety of sub-skills within these 5 categories.  The skills acknowledged by this badging system dovetail well with the course's CS content and help student's assess their own personal readiness for college and beyond.

The Thriving in Our Digital World curriculum is freely available online(http://www.cs.utexas.edu/~engage/) under a Creative Commons license for attributed non-commercial use.  On the CS Princeiples website, the course is listed as the one complete available curriculum.


Last Modified: 12/02/2016
Modified by: Calvin Lin
